review_title: Does not care about contract employees
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Saint Catharines, ON
pros: A decent university and good place to work day-to-day. Most coworkers are friendly and students are kind and down to earth (albeit not the brightest).
cons: The university does not care about contract employees. Instructors at the university are in the running for the lowest pay in the country. In fact, given the amount of work instructors need to do, in some cases Teaching Assistants make more per hour than instructors, which is absurd. After going a full year without a new collective bargaining agreement, the university only offered a 1% pay raise, no job security, and no benefits. This was amidst the pandemic, in which instructors were expected to pivot to online teaching, which, in my experience, is much more time intensive than in person teaching.

review_title: Residence Life Staff Member (Not a reflection of the institution as a whole)
job_title: Residence Life Staff in Saint Catharines, ON
pros:
-Getting to know students and resources around campus.
-Working with diverse group of people 
-Room for personal growth as a student
cons:
-Some rules for students are outdated and not realistic for the real world. 
-Students are treated like children by management and even dons as well. 
-Essentially a 24/7 job with little time off especially living with students (either on a floor or in a court). 
-Pay is less than minimum wage if all hours are counted together.
-Requires that you must pay for full meal plan if you do not request traditional style living
-Requires you to turn a blind eye to certain things in order to not have paperwork all the time and to manage your school life on top of staff life.

job_title: ITS in St. Catharines, ON
pros:
-Access to Facilities (gym, pool, etc.)
-There's some really great people there
-If you keep focused on helping the students, it helps one stay motivated
-Week off at Christmas
cons:
-Established staff treat new people terribly (especially in IT)
-there are LITTLE to NO training opportunities for IT staff, while a lot of the senior staff (many of which are not up to speed on technology at all) take these opportunities
-no plan for growth (although some thing that a job title change is a promotion...)
-many of their "enterprise" systems are stuck in the dark ages
-everyone has heard the term "old boys club" when referring to Brock... just look at the management relationships

job_title: Server/Bartender in Saint Catharines, ON
pros: Brock University Hospitality had great staff, everyone was very welcoming and kind. Staff were offered dinner when they were on shift if there was food at the event. Management did not micromanage.
cons: Unfortunately, due to the nature of the business, shifts were only available when there were hospitality events. Because of that, this job likely wouldn't be enough for someone who had to work regularly, but it was great for students!

review_title: Good pay and relaxed environment, but with little to no guidance
job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Catharines, ON
pros: As a research assistant, the pay is quite good.  There is no excess monitoring or micromanagement of your activities, and you also get great flexibility in the hours you work.
cons: You essentially do all research on your own, with little to no guidance from profs, etc... The bureaucracy at Brock can be quite irritating in its inability to assist you when things go wrong (you didn't receive your pay, etc.), and generally requires excessive paperwork and complicated procedures to get anything done.

job_title: Student Representative in Niagara, ON
pros: It is a smaller school that allowed for more intimate classes and experiences... You were challenged to make the most of everything that Niagara offered.
cons: Did not invest enough to relevant students of Brock. A lot of the infrastructure was not very good at the school and there was not enough room to play sports.
